Kwanzaa is a week-long African-American cultural celebration that was born in the 1960s.
Every day is represented by a principal or theme, and today's is Umoja or unity.
Now, back in 1966, educator Dr. Maulana Karenga created Kwanzaa to bring together African-Americans in celebration of heritage.
About a dozen activists staged a sit-in.
Police came to the building lobby and led them out in plastic handcuffs as fellow activists sang encouragement.
I once spoke with Karenga here at NPR about the meaning of Kwanzaa and why he created it, which you'll hear a piece of in just a second.

He gave me three reasons: One, to reconnect to our African roots; two, to give us a time to come together in celebration like other cultures do; and three - and this is the real emphasis of Kwanzaa - to underscore the importance of community and family values among black folks all over the world.
(Soundbite of archived interview)
In fact, that's one of the ways to explain Kwanzaa.
It's a celebration of family, community and culture, and of course, the hub and hinge on which the holiday turns.

All the community-earned values are called Nguzo Saba, which means the seven principles_ and they are first in Swahili and then in the English: Umoja, unity; Kujichagulia, self-determination; Ujima, collective work and responsibility; Ujamaa, cooperative economics; Nia, purpose; Kuumba, creativity; and Imani, faith.
